node.desc: Transcoding start time (in ms)
Transcoding duration (in ms)
This overrides the audio sampling rate parameter of input file
This overrides the number of audio channels parameter of input file
This overrides the video color space format of input file
This overrides the frame width parameter of input file
This overrides the frame height parameter of input file
This overrides the frame rate parameter of input file
This will override video bitrate settings with the value estimated from target file size. To make the estimation more accuate, please set audio encoder to bitrate-based. 0 to disable.

This will override video bitrate settings with the value estimated from target compression ratio against the original file. For example, to make the converted file half the size of the original, set this value to 2 (stand for 2:1). To make the estimation more accuate, please set audio encoder to bitrate-based. 0 to disable.
Whether to change the Aspect Ratio (Display Aspect Ratio or Pixel Aspect Ratio)

node.text: Override FourCC of output video stream

node.desc: A larger buffer results in better overall performance. It should not be larger than the available physical memory. 0 for auto.
Currently only effective for MP4Box and MKVMerge
Audio encoder options

LAME is an LGPL MP3 encoder. The Open source development model allowed to improve its quality and speed since 1999. It is now an highly evolved MP3 encoder, with quality and speed able to rival state of the art commercial encoders.
Specify minimum allowed bitrate, default 32 kbps
Specify maximum allowed bitrate, default 320 kbps
Ogg Vorbis is a completely open, patent-free, professional audio encoding and streaming technology with all the benefits of Open Source.

The FAAC project includes the AAC encoder FAAC and decoder FAAD2. It supports several MPEG-4 object types (LC, Main, LTP, HE AAC, PS) and file formats (ADTS AAC, raw AAC, MP4), multichannel and gapless en/decoding as well as MP4 metadata tags. The codecs are compatible with standard-compliant audio applications using one or more of these profiles.
Stores the bitstream as raw payload with extradata in the container header

It supports several MPEG-4 object types (LC, Main, LTP, HE AAC, PS) and file formats (ADTS AAC, raw AAC, MP4), multichannel and gapless en/decoding as well as MP4 metadata tags. The codecs are compatible with standard-compliant audio applications using one or more of these profiles.

node.enum: Explicit SBR and implicit PS signaling

node.desc: MPEG-4 aacPlus is the combination of three MPEG technologies comprising Advanced Audio Coding (AAC), coupled with Coding Technologies' Spectral Band Replication (SBR), and Parametric Stereo (PS) technologies. SBR is a unique bandwidth extension technique which enables audio codecs to deliver the same quality at half the bit rate. PS significantly increases the codec efficiency a second time for low bit rate stereo signals.
Nero Digital Audio Reference Quality MPEG-4 & 3GPP Audio Codec.
Dolby Digital Audio Encoder, encoding AC3 and E-AC3 format.

node.text: Write a VBRI header if vbr mode is active

node.desc: Musepack or MPC is an open source lossy audio codec, specifically optimized for transparent compression of stereo audio at bitrates of 160-180 kbit/s. It was formerly known as MPEGplus, MPEG+ or MP+.

FFmpeg is a collection of free software that can record, convert and stream digital audio and video. It includes libavcodec, a leading audio/video codec library. FFmpeg is developed under Linux, but it can be compiled under most operating systems, including Windows.

FFmpeg is a collection of free software that can record, convert and stream digital audio and video. It includes libavcodec, a leading audio/video codec library. FFmpeg is developed under Linux, but it can be compiled under most operating systems, including Windows.
The 3rd Generation Partnership Project (3GPP) is a collaboration agreement that was established in December 1998.
WavPack is a free, open source lossless audio compression format developed by David Bryant.

FLAC, an acronym for Free Lossless Audio Codec, is a popular format for audio compression. Unlike lossy codecs such as Vorbis, MP3 and AAC, it does not remove any information from the audio stream and is suitable both for everyday playback and audio archival. The FLAC format is currently well supported by many software projects and hardware support is growing.[1] FLAC also supports Replay Gain.

Monkey's Audio is a proprietary lossless audio compression codec. Unlike lossy formats, such as MP3, Ogg Vorbis, or AAC, Monkey's Audio does not permanently discard data during compression. A file compressed with Monkey's Audio sounds the same as the original file, no matter how many times it is uncompressed and reencoded.

OptimFROG is a lossless audio compression program. Its main goal is to reduce at maximum the size of audio files, while permitting bit identical restoration for all input. It is similar with the ZIP compression, but it is highly specialized to compress audio data.
Output to waveform or raw PCM file

node.text: Output in separated mono wave files

node.desc: Use any command line utility as encoder

node.text: Standard input as audio data input

node.desc: Buffer in msec for audio with peak bit rate-based VBR.
Video will be skipped over and audio will be muted and unmuted according to the entries in the given file.
Video encoder settings

XviD is a free and open source MPEG-4 video codec. It features MPEG-4 Advanced Simple Profile features such as b-frames, global and quarter pixel motion compensation, lumi masking, trellis quantization, and H.263, MPEG and custom quantization matrices.

Restricts options and VBV (peak bitrate over a short period) according to the Simple, Advanced Simple and DivX profiles. The resulting videos should be playable on standalone players adhering to these profile specifications.
If set, all options which may conflicts with profile specification will be disabled.

The motion search algorithm is based on a search in the usual color domain and tries to find a motion vector that minimizes the difference between the reference frame and the encoded frame. With this setting activated, XviD will also use the frequency domain (DCT) to search for a motion vector that minimizes not only the spatial difference but also the encoding length of the block.

This option controls the motion estimation subsystem. The higher the value, the more precise the estimation should be (default: 6). The more precise the motion estimation is, the more bits can be saved. Precision is gained at the expense of CPU time so decrease this setting if you need realtime encoding.
Maximum number of B-frames to put between I/P-frames
Make XviD discard chroma planes so the encoded video is greyscale only. Note that this does not speed up encoding, it just prevents chroma data from being written in the last stage of encoding.

MPEG-4 uses a half pixel precision for its motion search by default. The standard proposes a mode where encoders are allowed to use quarter pixel precision. This option usually results in a sharper image. Unfortunately it has a great impact on bitrate and sometimes the higher bitrate use will prevent it from giving a better image quality at a fixed bitrate. It is better to test with and without this option and see whether it is worth activating.

Enable Global Motion Compensation, which makes XviD generate special frames (GMC-frames) which are well suited for Pan/Zoom/ Rotating images. Whether or not the use of this option will save bits is highly dependent on the source material.

Trellis Quantization is a kind of adaptive quantization method that saves bits by modifying quantized coefficients to make them more compressible by the entropy encoder. Its impact on quality is good, and if VHQ uses too much CPU for you, this setting can be a good alternative to save a few bits (and gain quality at fixed bitrate) at a lesser cost than with VHQ
Activate this if your encoded sequence is an anime/cartoon. It modifies some XviD internal thresholds so XviD takes better decisions on frame types and motion vectors for flat looking cartoons.

Sets the type of quantizer to use. For high bitrates, you will find that MPEG quantization preserves more detail. For low bitrates, the smoothing of H.263 will give you less block noise. When using custom matrices, MPEG quantization must be used.

The usual motion estimation algorithm uses only the luminance information to find the best motion vector. However for some video material, using the chroma planes can help find better vectors. This setting toggles the use of chroma planes for motion estimation.

Enable a chroma optimizer prefilter. It will do some extra magic on color information to minimize the stepped-stairs effect on edges. It will improve quality at the cost of encoding speed. It reduces PSNR by nature, as the mathematical deviation to the original picture will get bigger, but the subjective image quality will raise. Since it works with color information, you might want to turn it off when encoding in greyscale.
Activates high-quality prediction of AC coefficients for intra frames from neighbor blocks

This option is meant to solve frame-order issues when encoding to container formats like AVI that cannot cope with out-of-order frames. In practice, most decoders (both software and hardware) are able to deal with frame-order themselves, and may get confused when this option is turned on, so you can safely leave if off, unless you really know what you are doing.

Dramatically speeds up pass one using faster algorithms and disabling CPU-intensive options. This will probably reduce global PSNR a little bit and change individual frame type and PSNR a little bit more.
Create n threads to run the motion estimation.

node.text: Maximum interval between I-frames (0 for auto)

node.desc: Percentage of compression performed on the high part of the curve (above average)
Percentage of compression performed on the high part of the curve (below average)
Payback delay expressed in number of frames
Percentage of allowed range for a frame that gets bigger because of overflow bonus
Percentage of allowed range for a frame that gets smaller because of overflow penalty
Maximum bitrate reduction applied to an iframe under the kfthreshold distance limit
If an iframe is closer to the next iframe than this distance, a quantity of bits is substracted from its bit allocation. The reduction is computed as multiples of kfreduction/kthreshold.
How many bytes the controller has to compensate per frame due to container format overhead

x264 is a free library for encoding H.264/MPEG-4 AVC video streams. It is released under the terms of the GPL License, but this license may be incompatible with the MPEG-LA patent licenses in jurisdictions that recognize software patents.

Set the bitstream's level as defined by annex A of the H.264 standard (default: 40 - Level 4.0). This is used for telling the decoder what capabilities it needs to support. Use this parameter only if you know what it means, and you have a need to set it. 0 for auto.

node.text: Use a preset to select encoding settings
Tune the settings for a particular type of source

node.desc: This selects the quantizer to use for P-frames. 20~40 is a useful range. Lower values result in better fidelity, but higher bitrates. 0 is lossless. Note that quantization in H.264 works differently from MPEG-1/2/4: H.264's quantization parameter (QP) is on a logarithmic scale.

Sets maximum interval between IDR-frames. Larger values save bits, thus improve quality, at the cost of seeking precision. Unlike MPEG-1/2/4, H.264 does not suffer from DCT drift with large values of keyint.

Sets minimum interval between IDR-frames. If scenecuts appear within this interval, they are still encoded as I-frames, but do not start a new GOP. In H.264, I-frames do not necessarily bound a closed GOP because it is allowable for a P-frame to be predicted from more frames than just the one frame before it. Therefore, I-frames are not necessarily seekable. IDR-frames restrict subsequent P-frames from referring to any frame prior to the IDR-frame.

node.text: How aggressively to insert extra I-frames
node.desc: Sets the threshold for I/IDR frame placement (read: scene change detection). Default is 40. x264 calculates a metric for every frame to estimate how different it is from the previous frame. If the value is lower than scenecut, a 'scenecut' is detected. An I-frame is placed if it has been less than --min-keyint frames since the last IDR-frame, otherwise an IDR-frame is placed. Higher values of scenecut increase the number of scenecuts detected. Setting scenecut to 0 is equivalent to setting --no-scenecut.

node.text: QP difference between chroma and luma
Frames used as predictors in B and P frames
node.desc: Number of previous frames used as predictors in B- and P-frames. This is effective in anime, but in live-action material the improvements usually drop off very rapidly above 6 or so reference frames. This has no effect on decoding speed, but does increase the memory needed for decoding. Some decoders can only handle a maximum of 15 reference frames.

node.text: Maximum B frames between I and P frames

node.desc: Automatically decides when to use B-frames and how many, up to the maximum specified above. If this option is disabled, then the maximum number of B-frames is used.
Keep some B-frames as references
Make x264 more likely to choose higher numbers of B-frames during the adaptive lookahead. Not generally recommended. Recommended default: 0

This adjusts thresholds for the H.264 in-loop deblocking filter. First, this parameter adjusts the maximum amount of change that the filter is allowed to cause on any one pixel. Secondly, this parameter affects the threshold for difference across the edge being filtered. A positive value reduces blocking artifacts more, but will also smear details.
This affects the detail threshold. Very detailed blocks are not filtered, since the smoothing caused by the filter would be more noticeable than the original blocking.
Use Context-Adaptive Binary Arithmetic Coding. Slightly slows down encoding and decoding, but should save 10-15% bitrate. Unless you are looking for decoding speed, you should not disable it.
10~30 seems to be a useful range.
Maximum value by which the quantizer may be incremented/decremented between frames
Maximum local bitrate, in kbits/second (0 for disabled)

node.text: Averaging period for maximum local bitrate
node.desc: Averaging period for vbv_maxrate, in kbits (default: none, must be specified if vbv_maxrate is enabled)
Initial buffer occupancy, as a fraction of vbv_bufsize
In 1-pass bitrate encodes, this settings controls the percentage that x264 can miss the target average bitrate by. Default is 1.0, lowest is 0.01.

node.text: I-frame quantizer increase compared to P-frame
node.desc: Modifies the target average increase in quantizer for I-frames as compared to P-frames. Higher values increase the quality of I-frames generated.

node.text: B-frame quantizer decrease compared to P-frame
node.desc: Modifies the target average decrease in quantizer for B-frames as compared to P-frames. Higher values decrease the quality of B-frames generated. Not used with mbtree (enabled by default), which calculates the optimum value automatically.

node.text: Number of frames for frame type lookahead

node.desc: Quantizer compression percentage. A lower value makes the bitrate more constant, while a higher value makes the quantization parameter more constant.

Determines the type of motion prediction used for direct macroblocks in B-frames. Spatial and temporal are approximately the same speed and PSNR, the choice between them depends on the video content. Auto is slightly better, but slower. direct_pred=0 is both slower and lower quality.

Use weighted prediction in B-frames. Without this option, bidirectionally predicted macroblocks give equal weight to each reference frame. With this option, the weights are determined by the temporal position of the B-frame relative to the references. Requires bframes > 1.
Enable all macroblock type including 8x4, 4x8 and 4x4. This is recommended only with subq >= 5, and only at low resolutions.
Adaptive spatial transform size: allows macroblocks to choose between 4x4 and 8x8 DCT. Also allows the i8x8 macroblock type. Without this option, only 4x4 DCT is used.
Select fullpixel motion estimation algorithm.
Radius of exhaustive or multi-hexagon motion search

Adjust subpel refinement quality. This parameter controls quality versus speed tradeoffs involved in the motion estimation decision process. subq=5 can compress up to 10% better than subq=1. 1: SAD mode decision, one qpel iteration 2: SATD mode decision 3-5: Progressively more qpel 6: RD mode decision for I/P-frames 7: RD mode decision for all frames 8: RD refinement for I/P-frames 9: RD refinement for all frames
Allows each 8x8 or 16x8 motion partition to independently select a reference frame. Without this option, a whole macroblock must use the same reference. Requires frameref > 1.

node.enum: Enabled only for the final encode

node.text: Reduce blocking and blurring in flat and texture areas
node.desc: Recommend range 0.0~2.0
Set the size of the intra luma quantization deadzone for non-trellis quantization. This option has the same effect as deadzone_inter except that it affects intra frames.

Set the size of the inter luma quantization deadzone for non-trellis quantization. Lower values help to preserve fine details and film grain (typically useful for high bitrate/quality encode), while higher values help filter out these details to save bits that can be spent again on other macroblocks and frames (typically useful for bitrate-starved encodes).

node.text: Performs early skip detection in P-frames
node.desc: Performs early skip detection in P-frames. This usually improves speed at no cost, but it can sometimes produce artifacts in areas with no details, like sky.

node.text: Eliminate DCT blocks with small coefficient
node.desc: Eliminate dct blocks in P-frames containing only a small single coefficient. This will remove some details, so it will save bits that can be spent again on other frames, hopefully raising overall subjective quality. If you are compressing non-anime content with a high target bitrate, you may want to disable this to preserve as much detail as possible.
0 means disabled. 100000 is a useful range for typical content, but you may want to turn it up a bit more for very noisy content

Causes SPS and PPS to appear only once, at the beginning of the bitstream. Some players, such as the Sony PSP, require the use of this option. The default behavior causes SPS and PPS to repeat prior to each IDR frame.

node.text: Set SPS and PPS id numbers
Number of slices per frame (0 for auto)

node.desc: Split each frame into slices and encode them in parallel. Also allows multithreaded decoding if the decoder supports it (lavc does not). This has a slight penalty to compression.
Slightly improve quality of SMP, at the cost of repeatability

Note that i8x8 requires 8x8dct, and is therefore a High Profile-only partition. p8x8 is the most costly, speed-wise, of the partitions, but also gives the most benefit. Generally, whenever possible, all partition types except p4x4 should be used.
Fast first pass mode. During the first pass of a two or more pass encode it is possible to gain speed by disabling some options with negligible or even no impact on the final pass output quality.

node.text: Save PSNR and SSIM to file
Increase MinQp by 10% when less than
Increase bitrate when minQp more than

node.desc: x265 is a free library for encoding HEVC video streams. It is released under the terms of the GPL License, but this license may be incompatible with the MPEG-LA patent licenses in jurisdictions that recognize software patents.
Enable or disable wavefront parallel processing
Enable or disable wavefront parallel processing
Enable or disable loop filter

node.text: Max CU width and height in pixels

node.desc: Adjust subpel refinement quality. This parameter controls quality versus speed tradeoffs involved in the motion estimation decision process.
Radius of exhaustive or multi-hexagon motion search

Sets maximum interval between IDR-frames. Larger values save bits, thus improve quality, at the cost of seeking precision. Unlike MPEG-1/2/4, H.264 does not suffer from DCT drift with large values of keyint.

node.text: How aggressively to insert extra I-frames
node.desc: Sets the threshold for I/IDR frame placement (read: scene change detection). Default is 40. x265 calculates a metric for every frame to estimate how different it is from the previous frame. If the value is lower than scenecut, a 'scenecut' is detected. An I-frame is placed if it has been less than --min-keyint frames since the last IDR-frame, otherwise an IDR-frame is placed. Higher values of scenecut increase the number of scenecuts detected. Setting scenecut to 0 is equivalent to setting --no-scenecut.

node.text: Frames used as predictors in B and P frames
node.desc: Number of previous frames used as predictors in B- and P-frames. This is effective in anime, but in live-action material the improvements usually drop off very rapidly above 6 or so reference frames. This has no effect on decoding speed, but does increase the memory needed for decoding. Some decoders can only handle a maximum of 15 reference frames.

node.text: Maximum B frames between I and P frames

node.desc: Enable or disable Open Gop
Automatically decides when to use B-frames and how many, up to the maximum specified above. If this option is disabled, then the maximum number of B-frames is used.
Enable or disable BPyramid
Maximum value by which the quantizer may be incremented/decremented between frames
In 1-pass bitrate encodes, this settings controls the percentage that x264 can miss the target average bitrate by. Default is 1.0, lowest is 0.01.
I-frame quantizer increase compared to P-frame. Higher values increase the quality of I-frames generated.
B-frame quantizer decrease compared to P-frame. Higher values decrease the quality of B-frames generated.

node.text: Number of frames for frame type lookahead

node.desc: Quantizer compression percentage. A lower value makes the bitrate more constant, while a higher value makes the quantization parameter more constant.
Use weighted prediction in B-framessition of the B-frame.
Use weighted prediction for P-frames.
Enable use of Cbf flags for fast mode decision.
Enable hiding one sign bit per TU via implicit signaling.
RD-penalty for 32x32 TU for intra in non-intra slices.
How AQ distributes bits
Reduce blocking and blurring in flat and texture areas. Recommend range 0.0~2.0
Split each frame into slices and encode them in parallel. Also allows multithreaded decoding if the decoder supports it (lavc does not). This has a slight penalty to compression.
Sets the maximum rate the VBV buffer should be assumed to refill at(default is 0).
Sets the size of the VBV buffer in kilobits. Default is zero.

Sets how full the VBV buffer must be before playback starts. If it is less than 1, then the initial fill is vbv-init * vbvBufferSize. Otherwise, it is interpreted as the initial fill in kbits. Default is 0.9
Enable CUTree ratecontrol. This keeps track of the CUs that propagate temporally across frames and assigns more bits to these CUs. Improves encode efficiency. Default: OFF (false) .
CUDA-enabled H.264 encoder
Force to select a gpu to encode, Default is -1, not to force selection.
Not to use multi gpu to encode but use a best gpu.
Encoder create device memory on a best gpu, and use device memory while encoding.

This moves the frame skipping (dropping) step of encoding from before the filter chain to some point during the filter chain. This allows filters which need to see all frames to function properly. Should be placed after the filters which need to see all frames and before any subsequent filters that are CPU-intensive.
Enabling this can avoid failure on some corrupted files but will bring a little overhead.

node.text: Use MEncoder's MPEG writer instead of LAVF

node.desc: This option is applicable when output container is set to MPEG

FFmpeg is a collection of free software that can record, convert and stream digital audio and video. It includes libavcodec, a leading audio/video codec library. FFmpeg is developed under Linux, but it can be compiled under most operating systems, including Windows.
Radius of motion search

node.text: Maximum interval between keyframes in frames

node.desc: 0 for encoder default
0 for encoder default

node.text: Minimum bitrate in kbit/sec (0 for unlimited)
Maximum bitrate in kbit/sec (0 for unlimited)
Buffer size in Kbit (0 for unlimited)
Copy timestamps from input to output
Packet size in bits (0 for default)
Perceptual weighting - vertical cycles per degree

node.desc: >0, typically: 7=medium, 9=high

node.text: Use spatial partitioning while coding transform data

node.desc: The name of the binary codec file with which to encode (e.g. divx.dll)

node.text: Codec settings file for second pass

node.desc: Buffer in msec for video with peak bit rate-based VBR.
VC-1 Encoder is developed by MS based on WMV9, SMPTE compliant WVC1 implementation, used for HD Video/Bluray Disc.

Containing the encoder complexity level. A value of 0 offers the best performance. A value of 5 offers the best quality.For offline encoding, use level 3 for a good balance of quality and encoding speed. Lower values produce much lower quality and higher values may result in much longer encoding time with only small improvements in quality. For live encoding, use the highest value that does not drop frames.

Containing the fixed quantization parameter for 1-pass VBR encoding or the maximum QP for 1-pass and 2-pass CBR encoding. For 1-pass VBR, this value represents the quality of the encoding. Lower values will provide better visual quality, but will use more bits per frame. Generally values below 8 yield good results and values above 8 may show distracting artifacts.For 1-pass CBR, this represents the maximum frame QP. If there are not enough bits for the next frame to be at or below the maximum frame QP, then that frame will not be encoded, and those bits will be allocated to the subsequent frame. Thus, a lower fixed QP may result in dropped frames. In general, you should choose the highest value that provides the minimum acceptable visual quality in order to reduce the number of dropped frames.

Containing the maximum distance between key frames. Must be greater than or equal to NumOfBFrames + 1. Refer to target media specifications for maximum key frame distance requirements. The HD DVD specification requires the key frame distance to be less than 0.6006 sec. Use an appropriate number based on the desired frame rate.
Containing the number of B-frames between key frames. Must be zero when using Simple profile. Recommendation: 1.
The peak bit rate, used only when rate control mode is 2-pass peak constrained VBR.

The range depends on the profile. The range is 1 to 157696 for Simple profile, 1 to 5001216 for Main profile, and 1 to 33792000 for Advanced profile. Not used when rate control mode is 1-pass VBR with fixed QP.

When you specify Yes, the encoder resets the GOP at each key frame. The encoder can insert key frames either for scene changes or because the maximum key frame distance has been reached. When you specify No, the encoder maintains a regular key frame cadence, but the encoder may still insert extra scene change key frames.

The default is the number of logical processors available. Specifying 3 processors is not supported. Recommendation:One thread for pictures less than 128 rows in height, two threads for pictures between 128 and 256 rows, and four threads for larger pictures.
Specifying Yes enables preprocessing modules such as flash detection, which enables the encoder to intelligently place B frames and I frames to optimize compression.
The default is 0, indicating that key pop reduction is disabled.Higher values specify stronger key pop reduction. Recommendation:Off unless key frame popping is visible.

This feature enables the codec to determine the location of letterbox matte bars at the top and bottom of each frame. When detected, the letterboxing is excluded from motion search operations, saving some bits and speeding up encoding.
Only set it if you must set a specific value. By default(0), the encoder will use dynamic B frame delta QP settings.

Closed GOPs are mainly used for chapter points on optical discs. They are not required for Windows Media. Recommendation:No for WMV files. Yes only at chapter points for optical discs or when streaming WMV.

0:Progressive video. 1:The VC-1 encoder encodes all frames as interlaced frames. This method is suitable for content that does not contain fast motion. Best when the content contains random motion. 2:The VC-1 encoder encodes all frames as pairs of interlaced fields. This is usually the most efficient method, especially if the content contains fast motion, such as panning. 3:The VC-1 encoder automatically determines the most efficient interlaced encoding method (frame or field). This method is suitable for content that does not contain fast motion. 4:The VC-1 encoder automatically determines the most efficient encoding method (frame, field, or progressive). This is the best method for content that contains a mixture of frame and field types.
Yes for noisy content, No for clean content.
Yes indicating in-loop filter is enabled. Default value depending on the profile. The default is Yes for Main and Advanced profiles. Must be No for Simple profile.

The median filter improves motion estimation processing by factoring out noise artifacts. This can improve the quality of very noisy video and reduce the size of the compressed data. Note that this filter is not the same as median blur filters found in many video editing and post-processing applications. Because the median filter can introduce trailing artifacts behind moving objects, you should disable this filter for source video that does not contain visible noise artifacts.

The encoder default is No for complexity level zero and Yes for other complexity levels. The overlap smoothing filter helps to reduce blocking artifacts by smoothing the borders between adjacent macroblocks. This tends to make the image appear softer, but can improve the appearance of low bit rate video that contains many blocking artifacts.

The noise edge removal filter detects noise in frame edges and removes it. The noise edge detection only works for frame edges that contain three lines of noise, or less. The filter copies lines adjacent to the noisy lines to complete the frame.

specifying the method used to code the motion vector information in field pictures. This property is for interlaced content only and most useful for unpredictable motion. Specify 0 except for Advanced profile and interlaced encoding. 0:Off(Default). 1:Improves coding efficiency for highly spread-out horizontal delta motion vector distributions. 2:Improves coding efficiency for highly spread-out vertical delta motion vector distributions. 3:Improves coding efficiency for highly spread-out horizontal and vertical delta motion vector distributions.

The default depends on the complexity level. 0:Luma only.Provides fastest performance (encoding speed). 1:Luma with nearest integer chroma. Provides a compromise between quality and performance. 2:Luma with true chroma. Provides the best quality with the lowest performance. 3:Macroblock adaptive with nearest integer chroma. Provides a compromise between quality and performance. Macroblock adaptive with true chroma. Provides a compromise between quality and performance.

The default depends on the complexity level. 0:SAD. Provides the best performance. 1:Hadamard. Provides the best quality. 2:Macroblock-adaptive. This option configures the codec to make decisions about which method to use on each macroblock. This can potentially reduce overall computation required for encoding by performing the computationally-intensive Hadamard transform only when appropriate.

specifying the cost method used by the codec to determine which macroblock mode to use. The default is 0 when encoder complexity is less than 2. Otherwise, the default is 1. 0:SAD/Hadamard. This option configures the codec to account for only distortion when computing cost. 1:RD cost. This option configures the codec to account for both rate and distortion when computing cost.

specifying the method used by the codec to estimate the amount of processing required for motion vector coding. 0:Static method. This option uses the same motion vector cost estimate for all macroblocks. 1:Dynamic method. This option varies the motion vector cost between macroblocks to achieve optimal visual quality. Setting 1 DQuant option is not used. Otherwise, use setting 0.
specifying the range used in motion searches. Specify 0 when using Simple profile.
Higher values mean stronger quantization. 0:Off(default). 1~15:Conservative range. 16~20:Strong range.

Specify 0 for Simple profile or 1-pass VBR. Specify 0 when using hardware acceleration. 0:Off. 1:Only I-frames will be optimized. 2:I,P frames will be optimized. 3:I,P, and B frames will be optimized. Recommendation: 0 for moderate to low bitrates (anything under 15 Mbps for HD). 2 for high-bit-rate encoding. DQuant can improve video quality in smooth areas containing very fine detail or gradients, or very dark uniform areas because those areas are prone to blocking artifacts at high quantizer levels.

Specifying the strength of the Dquant perceptual optimization that will be used for P frames. The stronger the optimization, the more CPU-intensive the encoding will be. Default is 0 (off). Higher values correspond to stronger optimization. Specify 0 for Simple profile or 1-pass VBR. Must be non-zero when dwDQuantOption is 2 or 3. Otherwise, this value must be zero. Recommendation: 0 for most content. Try setting 1 if you notice blocking in smooth regions after initial encoding and setting 2 if you still see blocking after trying setting 1.

Specifying the strength of the Dquant perceptual optimization that will be used for B frames. The stronger the optimization, the more CPU-intensive the encoding will be. The default is 0 (off) Other possible values range from 1 to 4. Higher values correspond to stronger optimization.Specify 0 for Simple profile or 1-pass VBR. Must be non-zero when dwDQuantOption is 3. Otherwise, this value must be zero.
Yes indicating that color formats will be applied to the video.

MP4Box is an MPEG-4 converter. It can import MPEG-4 video (DivX/XviD/3ivx/ffmpeg) and audio streams into the *.mp4 container. The end result is ISO compliant MPEG-4 streams. It can also produce MPEG-4 Timed Text streams by importing subtitles formats such as srt.

node.text: Packed bitstream when importing raw ASP
Rewrites the file as an ISMA 1.0 AV file
Stores file with all media data first
Interleaves file data (track chunks of time in ms)

node.desc: If frag > 0, will disable inter option. Audio/video data will not interleaved.
ISO Media file major brand, ex. mp42/3gp4/3gp5/3gp6/isom
Default is 0

Matroska is a universal audio/video container format. It aims to become the standard of multimedia container formats. It was derived from a project called MCF, but differentiates from it significantly because it is based on EBML (Extensible Binary Meta Language), a binary derivative of XML. EBML enables the Matroska Development Team to gain significant advantages in terms of future format extensibility, without breaking file support in old parsers.
0 for current video bitrate

AVI is a multimedia container format introduced by Microsoft in 1992, as part of the Video for Windows technology. AVI files contain both audio and video data in a standard container that allows simultaneous playback. Like DVDs, AVI files support multiple audio and video streams, although these features are rarely used. Most AVI files also use the file format extensions developed by the Matrox OpenDML group in February 1996. These files are supported by Microsoft, and are known unofficially as AVI 2.0.

node.text: Do not write OpenDML index for AVI files
Maximum payload size for RTP packets in hint track

node.desc: PMP format is a container specially designed for realize full motion, high quality video playback on PSP.
VCDImager is a full-featured mastering suite for authoring, disassembling and analyzing Video CD's and SuperVideo CD's.
Audio filters allow you to modify the audio stream and its properties. (Appliable with MPlayer source only)
Changes the sample rate of the audio stream.

Output sample frequency in Hz. The valid range for this parameter is 8000 to 192000. If the input and output sample frequency are the same or if this parameter is omitted the filter is automatically unloaded. A high sample frequency normally improves the audio quality, especially when used in combination with other filters.
Down-sampling only, that is, do resampling only when target frequency is lower than the original.
Disallow the output frequency to differ slightly from the specified frequency given.
Selects which resampling method to use.
Uses resampler provided by libavcodec
10 octave band graphic equalizer, implemented using 10 IIR band pass filters. This means that it works regardless of what type of audio is being played back.

Can be used for adding, removing, routing and copying audio channels. If only number of channel is specified the default routing is used, it works as follows: If the number of output channels is bigger than the number of input channels empty channels are inserted (except mixing from mono to stereo, then the mono channel is repeated in both of the output channels). If the number of output channels is smaller than the number of input channels the exceeding channels are truncated.
Mix left and right channel, and then output to sterel or mono.
Software volume control
Use replay gain method to get volume gain of audio track.
Used to calculate replay gain of audio track.
Sets the desired gain in dB for all channels in the stream from -200dB to +60dB, where -200dB mutes the sound completely and +60dB equals a gain of 1000
Soft-clipping can make the sound more smooth if very high volume levels are used. Enable this option if the dynamic range of the loudspeakers is very low.
Maximizes the volume without distorting the sound. Mode 1/2: Use a single/several sample to smooth the variations via the standard weighted mean over past samples.
Sets the target amplitude as a fraction of the maximum for the sample type
Decoder for matrix encoded surround sound like Dolby Surround. Many files with 2 channel audio actually contain matrixed surround sound. Requires a sound card supporting at least 4 channels

node.text: Delay time in ms for the rear speakers
node.desc: Delay time in ms for the rear speakers (0 to 1000).
Delays the sound to the loudspeakers such that the sound from the different channels arrives at the listening position simultaneously. It is only useful if you have more than 2 loudspeakers.
(Linearly) increases the difference between left and right channels which adds some sort of live effect to playback.
Video filters allow you to modify the video stream and its properties.
Scales the image with the software scaler (slow) and performs a YUV-RGB colorspace conversion

This param depends on scale algorithm: If algorithm is 'Bicubic' or 'Gauss', the value range is:0(soften)~100(sharpen). If algorithm is 'Lanczos', the value represent for filter length(1~10), 0 means scaling according to w/h of target size.
Crops the given part of the image and discards the rest. Useful to remove black bands from widescreen movies.
Left position of the cropped picture, 0 for center.
Top position of the cropped picture, 0 for center.
Cropped width, 0 for original width
Cropped height, 0 for original height
Increase or decrease right edge when auto crop, must be even number.
Increase or decrease bottom edge when auto crop, must be even number.
Threshold of crop detector, which can be optionally specified from nothing (0) to everything (255)
Expands (not scales) movie resolution to the given value and places the unscaled original at coordinates x, y. Can be used for placing subtitles/OSD in the resulting black bands.

node.text: Determine if expand is after scale

node.desc: Expanded width (0 for original width). Negative value is treated as offsets to the original width.
Expanded height (0 for original height). Negative value is treated as offsets to the original height.
X position of original image on the expanded image (0 for center).
Y position of original image on the expanded image (0 for center).
Output frame rate settings
Force decoder to output at detected frame rate

node.text: Force duplicate frames to be encoded

node.desc: Software equalizer that uses lookup tables, allowing gamma correction in addition to simple brightness and contrast adjustment.
Range: 0.1~10
Range: 0.1~10
Range: 0.1~10
Picture visual quality enhancement
Automatic brightness / contrast correction
Rotates the image by 90 degrees and optionally flips it.

node.text: Mirrors the image on the Y axis

node.desc: Attempts to reverse the 'telecine' process to recover a clean, non-interlaced stream at film framerate.
This filter aims to reduce image noise producing smooth images and making still images really still (This should enhance compressibility.).

node.text: Thickness of the fuzzy edge of the rectangle

node.desc: Allows acquiring screenshots of the movie using the screenshot command (bound to the 's' key by default). Files named 'shotNNNN.png' will be saved in the working directory, using the first available number - no files will be overwritten. The filter has no overhead when not used and accepts an arbitrary colorspace, so it is safe to add it to the configuration file.
Take a screenshot after the specified interval (seconds). Set to 0 for never taking a screenshot.
Range 0~100, 100 stands for best quality.
Crop or expand to maintain aspect(no distortion).
0 for end of file
The interval of the point to generate thumbnail will be automatically calcluated with this value and the start/end time specified above.
Stitch thumbnails into a large image.
How to align thumbnails on the stitching image(When stitching is enabled).
Append suffix with size to thumb file name for different output size.

node.text: Number of logo position and time interval
Waiting time(second) when logo move to the end of route.

node.desc: 'x':moving along x axis, 'y':moving along y axis, 'd':moving along diagonal line, the 3 types of routes can be joined with ',' to use multiple routes.
